CreateAutoScalingGroup.document: This example shows how to create an auto scaling group in a specified VPC and configure a layer-7 load balancer.
CreateAutoScalingGroup.title: Creating an auto scaling group

CreateAutoScalingGroupFromInstance.title: Creating launch configuration and scaling group based on an instance

CreateLaunchConfiguration.document: Only assign values for the required parameters (launch configuration name, instance model, and image ID) and use system default values for other parameters. The specific configuration is as follows: launch configuration name: as_test, instance model: Standard II 1C1G (S2.SMALL1), image ID: img-8toqc6s3.
CreateLaunchConfiguration.title: Creating Using Only the Required Parameters

CreateLaunchConfiguration.document: Launch configuration name: as_test; image ID: img-8toqc6s3; model: Standard II 1C1G (S2.SMALL1); system disk: 50 GB local disk; data disk: 100 GB HDD cloud disk; internet billing method: pay-as-you-go by traffic on an hourly basis; upper limit for internet bandwidth: 5 Mbps; IP: public IP; login method: key; Cloud Monitor and Cloud Security: installed.
CreateLaunchConfiguration.title: Creating Using Detailed Parameters

CreateLaunchConfiguration.document: Launch configuration name: spot-test; model: Standard II 2C4G (S2.MEDIUM4); billing method: bidding (SPOTPAID);
CreateLaunchConfiguration.title: Creating a Spot Instance Configuration

CreateLaunchConfiguration.document: This supports two instance models, namely, S2.SMALL2 and S2.SMALL4.
CreateLaunchConfiguration.title: Creating a Launch Configuration that Supports Multiple Instance Models

CreateLifecycleHook.document: This example shows you how to create a lifecycle hook that takes effect upon instance termination, where `DefaultResult` is set to `ABANDON` and `HeartbeatTimeout` is set to 120 seconds to notify the CMQ topic named `one-topic`.
CreateLifecycleHook.title: Creating a lifecycle hook to notify a CMQ topic

CreateLifecycleHook.document: This example shows you how to create a lifecycle hook that takes effect upon instance creation, where `DefaultResult` takes the default value `CONTINUE` and `HeartbeatTimeout` takes the default value 300 seconds.
CreateLifecycleHook.title: Creating a lifecycle hook with default values

CreateLifecycleHook.document: This example shows you how to create a lifecycle hook that takes effect upon instance creation, where `DefaultResult` is set to CONTINUE and `HeartbeatTimeout` is set to 120 seconds to notify the CMQ queuing model named "one-queue".
CreateLifecycleHook.title: Creating a lifecycle hook to notify a CMQ queue

CreateLifecycleHook.document: This example shows you how to create a lifecycle hook that takes effect upon instance creation, where `DefaultResult` is set to ABANDON and `HeartbeatTimeout` is set to 360 seconds.
CreateLifecycleHook.title: Creating a lifecycle hook

CreateNotificationConfiguration.title: Creating notifications for successful and failed scale-out events

CreatePaiInstance.document: This example shows you how to create a public address instance with specified parameters such as domain name.
CreatePaiInstance.title: Creating one public address instance

CreateScalingPolicy.title: Increasing the desired capacity by one if the average CPU utilization is over 50% within 1 minute for 5 consecutive occurrences
Removing 50% instances if the average memory utilization is below 35% within 1 minute for 5 consecutive occurrences

CreateScheduledAction.document: This example shows you how to create a scheduled action to adjust the maximum, minimum, and desired capacity of the scaling group to 10, 4, and 6 respectively at 23:00, August 28, 2018 (UTC+8).
CreateScheduledAction.title: Creating a single-run scheduled action

CreateScheduledAction.document: This example shows you how to create a scheduled action to adjust the maximum, minimum, and desired capacity of a scaling group to 7, 2, and 3 respectively at 23:00 every day starting from August 28, 2018 and ending at 00:00, January 1, 2019 (UTC+8).
CreateScheduledAction.title: Creating a recurring scheduled action

UpgradeLaunchConfiguration.document: This example shows you how to upgrade a launch configuration by only assigning values for the required parameters (launch configuration name, instance model, and image ID) and using system default values for other parameters. The specific configuration is as follows: launch configuration name: as_test, instance model: Standard II 1C1G (S2.SMALL1), image ID: img-8toqc6s3.
UpgradeLaunchConfiguration.title: Upgrading a launch configuration with simple parameters

UpgradeLaunchConfiguration.document: This example shows you how to upgrade a launch configuration with the following configurations. Launch configuration name: as_test; image ID: img-8toqc6s3; model: Standard II 1C1G (S2.SMALL1); system disk: 50 GB local disk; data disk: 100 GB HDD cloud disk; public billing method: pay-as-you-go by traffic on an hourly basis; public network bandwidth cap: 5 Mbps; public IP: assigned; login method: key; Cloud Monitor service: enabled, Anti-DDoS: enabled
UpgradeLaunchConfiguration.title: Upgrading a launch configuration with detailed parameters
